title: Forms
summary: Good spacing makes forms easier to read, scan, and complete. It helps users see how fields relate to each other, creates a clear hierarchy, and ensures enough room for focus states and touch targets. Consistent spacing makes forms feel structured and effortless to use.

columns.content:
Spacing in a field group should follow a consistent structure both vertically and horizontally, and reflect how fields are grouped semantically.

Field groups should be represented both visually and in code. Fields that belong together should be grouped using `<fieldset>` and `<legend>`, and the spacing should reinforce that structure.

Vertical spacing is used to separate and define field groups. Fields within the same `<fieldset>` should have smaller spacing between them, while the space between different fieldsets should be larger. This makes the grouping clear and consistent. Use consistent vertical spacing within each fieldset and between fieldsets to create a calm, structured flow and support quick scanning.

When fields are placed side by side, their spacing should follow the grid gaps to stay consistent with the overall layout. This means the gap will vary between screen sizes, adapting to the grid defined for each breakpoint. This creates a balanced rhythm in the form.  

Avoid placing fields side by side if it risks reducing readability or accessibility, for example, when labels or helper texts vary in length, or when users need to compare or enter longer text values. In those cases, stacking fields vertically provides better clarity and flow.

Sections are used to group related fields under a common heading. Clear spacing between sections helps users scan and understand the form structure, making longer forms easier to navigate.

Use consistent section spacing to build rhythm and hierarchy. As a guideline, section spacing should be about two to times larger than the spacing between fields (if field spacing is XL (24), section spacing can be 2XL (48)). If a divider is used between sections, the spacing above and below the divider can be slightly smaller since the divider already provides a visual separation.

sections.title: Form contexts
sections.section-content:
On mobile, fields are usually displayed in a single column and stretch to full width for easier scanning and touch interaction.

On larger screens, related fields can be placed side by side within the grid, as long as readability and accessibility are maintained.

sections.title: Spacing can vary depending on complexity of the form
sections.section-content: When a form contains many fields within a group, the vertical spacing often needs to increase to avoid a dense and overwhelming appearance. For simple forms, use XL (24) between fields. For more complex forms with many fields, increase to 2XL (32). The spacing between groups can remain the same to keep a consistent rhythm.

columns.content:
Density variants of form components allow forms to adapt to different use cases. The default layout uses comfortable spacing for readability, while a compact version can be used in data-heavy contexts where users need to see and edit many fields at once.

The spacing between fields in a compact variant with a horisontal layout should not follow the grid in these cases, the margins need to work independently to maintain a balanced and readable form layout. The grid itself doesn’t adapt to density.

To keep forms easy to read, limit the maximum width of the form container on large screens. We have set a max width for the large components of 420px. Very wide forms can make it harder for users to follow the flow or connect labels with fields.

For the compact versions this decreases to 320 on desktop. In a mobile device input components can always take the full width.
